column1: The Amazon represents over half of the planet's remaining rainforests and comprises the largest and most species-rich tract of tropical rainforest in the world. Wet tropical forests are the most species-rich biome
column2: and tropical forests in the Americas are consistently more species-rich than the wet forests in Africa and Asia. As the largest tract of tropical rainforest in the Americas
column3: the Amazonian rainforests have unparalleled biodiversity. More than 1/3 of all species in the world live in the Amazon Rainforest.

column1: The region of present-day Acre is thought to have been inhabited by Pre-Columbian civilizations since at least 2
column2: 100 years ago. Evidence includes complex geoglyphs of this age found in the area. The natives who crafted them are believed to have had a relatively advanced knowledge of this technology. Since at least the early 15th century
column3: the region has been inhabited by peoples who spoke Panoan languages; their territory was geographically close to that of the Inca.

column2: the region was colonized by the Spanish and became part of the Viceroyalty of Peru. Following the Peruvian and Bolivian wars of independence
column3: which ended in 1826
column4: the region and large portions around it became part of Bolivia
column5: but independent of Spain. It was a territory of the short-lived Peru–Bolivian Confederation (1836–1839)
column6: until the two countries separated and the region returned to Bolivian control.

column1: The discovery of rubber tree groves in the region in the mid-19th century attracted numerous immigrants
column2: especially from Brazil and Europe
column3: seeking to build on the rubber boom. Despite the increased numbers of Brazilians
column4: the Treaty of Ayacucho (1867) determined that the region belonged to Bolivia. By 1877
column5: Acre's population was composed almost entirely of Brazilians coming from the Northeast.

column2: Brazilian settlers from Acre created an independent state in the region called the Republic of Acre. Bolivians tried to gain control of the area
column3: but Brazilians revolted and there were border confrontations. This resulted in what was known as the Acre War. On November 17
column5: with the signing over and sale in the Treaty of Petrópolis
column6: Brazil received final possession of the region. Acre was integrated into Brazil as a territory divided into three departments. The territory was acquired by Brazil for two million pounds sterling. The land was taken from Mato Grosso in accordance with terms for the construction of the Madeira-Mamoré railway.

column10: Portuguese expeditions reached many of the far ends of present-day Brazil. The expansion of the exploration to the west followed
column11: and they reached lands under control by the Spanish colonies. The two nations negotiated to establish their territories

Both of the treaties were based on the explorations of Portuguese bandeirante Manoel Félix de Lima of the Guaporé and Madeira river basins. The treaties established the riverbeds of the Mamoré and Guaporé to their maximum western limits on the left bank of the Javari as the border between the Spanish and Portuguese territories.

Rio Branco International Airport is located in a rural zone of the municipality of Rio Branco
column2: in the state of Acre. It was opened on November 2

Rio Branco Airport serves domestic and international flights (by scheduled carriers and air taxi firms) along with general and military aviation. The terminal can receive 270 thousand passengers a year and serves an average of 14 daily operations.
